text: hello this is chef Juan from food wishes
calm with michelada that's right I
normally don't drink beer while
producing these videos but this time I
really had no choice because the Mischa
Lata is a spicy amazingly refreshing
beer based cocktail and pretty much the
ultimate hot weather adult beverage and
while I will admit drinking beer made
this production a little harder it also
made everyone slightly more attractive
but anyway let's go ahead and get
started and let me show you how I make
my Mischa Ladas so normally these are
made with a little splash of tomato
juice but what I like to do is make a
fresh vegetable juice using some of
these toy box Tomatoes which i think is
really going to give us a much fresher
much more vine ripened tomato flavor and
during the summer these are not hard to
find but really any variety of cherry
tomatoes should work and then to add to
the vegetable goodness we will also add
a little bit of celery
trishal II people use a pinch of celery
salt in this but since we're making our
own juice I figured let's use some fresh
and then last but not least we'll do a
little sweet red bell pepper and of
course if you want an extra spicy
version you can certainly use some fresh
hot peppers here maybe a Fresno chili or
even a habanero if you are muy machismo
by the way like bowling my Spanish gets
much better after a few beers and then
all we need to do to prep this is
transfer it into a blender and process
this until we have something very smooth
so we'll pulse it a few times to get it
started and then let it run on high for
a few seconds until we have something
that looks like this and at that point
what we'll do is we'll transfer that
into a strainer because personally I
think we should remove those seeds and
skins plus it's only going to take an
extra minute so I'm gonna go ahead and
use a spatula to push that through and
what we should be left with is something
that's very sweet very fresh tasting
sort of the liquid essence of a summer
garden and then once our juice is
properly I like to do is wrap it up and
keep it in the fridge so it's nice and
ice-cold when we go to make our mission
ADO's and by the way if it sits there a
long time it can separate so if you do
prep this ahead make sure you give it a
good whisk game before you use it but
anyway like I said we're going to wrap
that up and leave it in the fridge until
we need it and that leaves us with just
one optional job to do before we put
these micheladas together and that would
be the of the glass so what I
suggest we do is sprinkle some flaky
salt on a plate on top of which we will
add some freshly ground black pepper as
well as any type of red ground chili
pepper
you could use paprika smoked paprika
Chipotle heck even cayenne would work
here which is obviously what I used and
then one sour spicy salt mixture is
prepped all we have to do is take a cut
piece of lime and use that to moisten
the rim of our glass and then we'll
invert it and sort of tap it into our
mixture which is going to coat the rim
as seen so pretty much exactly the same
technique we use for margaritas and then
once our glass is prepped we can fill it
up with ice and don't be shy with the
ice fill it right up in my opinion the
colder these things are the better they
taste and before we add our two main
ingredients which is our fresh tomato
juice in beer we want to add a few very
important additional ingredients the
first of which would be a few dashes of
Worcestershire sauce I'm getting better
at that word and then we're also going
to do a couple drops of soy sauce for a
little extra hit of savoriness and also
so I can use the word umami in the
blogpost and then we're definitely going
to need some hot sauce I'm using a very
popular Mexican variety but any pepper
sauce will work and at this point I'm
going to pour in a splash of our
homemade tomato vegetable juice and I'm
not really putting that much because I
do like my micheladas being mostly beer
so I'm only putting in about a quarter
of a cup and then after our tomato
mixture goes in maybe the third most
important ingredients we need some fresh
lime juice so I'm going to squeeze in
the juice of half a lime and then last
but not certainly least we're going to
top this off with some ice-cold Mexican
lager and usually I would say to use any
style of beer you want but I really do
think an inexpensive lager works best
here
but that's up to you and your cabeza to
decide which cerveza and the method I
like to use is to fill it up about 3/4
of the way first and then take a spoon
or one of these fancy bartender stirs
and we'll give that a little stir to mix
all our components together and by the
way when bartenders do this is just not
to mix stuff up when you move those ice
cubes around like this it actually makes
the drink holder so we'll give that a
good mix at which point we will finish
topping it off with our ice cold cerveza
and then we'll garnish very simply with
a thin slice of lime that I definitely
cut before I started drinking in our
mission Lata at least the chef Jon
version is done and it might just be the
beer talking but to me that looks
exactly exactly like one of those pink
orange summer sunsets but don't get me
wrong nobody's drinking these things
because of how they look they're
drinking these because they're
incredibly tasty and on
believably refreshing and it seems like
we have a lot going on in here but it's
actually a very very light drink and not
heavy at all oh and speaking of heavy
did I ever mention a long time ago I
used to be able to benchpress 200 pounds
almost 200 pounds oh yeah but anyway
that's it
chef john's official version of Mischa
Lata and I realize if you've never had
one of these before you could be
skeptical I mean when I first heard
about this I was like beer tomato juice
hot sauce and lime that sounds horrible
but when you try one of these especially
if it's like 95 in the shade you will
understand so I really do hope you give
this a try head over to food wishes comm
for all the ingredient amounts and more
info as usual and as always enjoy
responsibly
